body:
DebianPrep is a lightweight automation script designed to simplify the process of configuring new Debian-based servers. Whether you’re setting up a local virtual machine or connecting to a remote VPS, DebianPrep helps you get a clean, ready-to-code environment in minutes.

Definition: DebianPrep automates the installation of essential tools, utilities, and system configurations that are commonly needed right after deploying a fresh Debian or Ubuntu server.

🚀 Purpose

When you spin up a new server, you often repeat the same initial setup tasks: updating packages, installing common utilities, configuring firewalls, enabling SSH, and more. DebianPrep automates all these actions through a single command.

🖥️ Supported Systems

DebianPrep supports all Debian-based Linux distributions, including:

  • Ubuntu (20.04 and newer)
  • Debian (10 and newer)
  • Linux Mint
  • Pop!_OS and more

⚙️ Features

  • Automatic package updates and upgrades
  • Installs essential tools: curl, wget, git, ufw, htop
  • Sets up SSH and basic firewall rules
  • Creates a system cleanup and optimization routine
  • Fast and idempotent; safe to run multiple times

📦 Installation

To run DebianPrep, simply execute the following command after connecting to your new Debian-based server:

bash
curl -L -o debianprep https://github.com/doe-base/debianprep/releases/download/v1.0.0/debianprep
chmod +x debianprep
./debianprep

This will download the script from the official GitHub repository and execute it immediately.

🧰 What It Installs

CategoryTools
Networkingcurl, wget, net-tools, openssh-server
System Utilitieshtop, unzip, tar, ufw, git
Developmentbuild-essential, pkg-config, make

🔧 Usage

DebianPrep can be used on any fresh Debian-based system. Run it immediately after gaining SSH access:

bash
ssh user@your-server-ip
curl -L -o debianprep https://github.com/doe-base/debianprep/releases/download/v1.0.0/debianprep
chmod +x debianprep
sudo mv debianprep /usr/local/bin/
debianprep

The script handles everything automatically. Once complete, your environment will be updated and ready for use.

🧠 Behind the Scenes

DebianPrep is written in Go and structured using modular internal commands for maintainability. Each command handles a distinct setup area; such as user creation, package installation, and security configuration.

📘 License

DebianPrep is released under the MIT License. Feel free to modify and reuse it for your own setup workflows.

🔗 Reference

Source: GitHub Repository

Net Reader is a learning-focused network exploration tool built to understand how devices discover and communicate with each other inside a Local Area Network (LAN). It combines a Golang backend with a React frontend to visualize network interfaces, IP addressing, and live peer discovery in real time.

Definition: Net Reader is a local web application that inspects network interfaces, discovers other devices running the same app on a LAN, and provides a foundation for peer-to-peer communication without relying on external servers.

🎯 Purpose

Modern applications often hide how networking actually works. Net Reader was built to demystify LAN networking by exposing core concepts such as IP addressing, network interfaces, broadcast-based discovery, and peer presence.

The project prioritizes learning and visibility over abstraction, making it useful for developers interested in networking, systems programming, and distributed systems fundamentals.

🖥️ Platform

  • OS Support: Linux only
  • Architecture: Browser-based UI communicating with a local Go server
  • Network Scope: Local Area Network (LAN)

⚙️ Core Features

  • Automatic LAN peer discovery using UDP broadcast
  • Network interface inspection (WiFi, Ethernet, USB tethering)
  • Local IP address and gateway visibility
  • Live list of discovered peers running Net Reader on the same LAN
  • Peer presence tracking with automatic expiry

🔬 What Net Reader Teaches

  • How devices identify themselves on a LAN
  • Why LAN discovery works without internet access
  • UDP broadcasting and listening mechanics
  • Network interface behavior and routing rules
  • Peer discovery patterns used by real-world systems

🧠 Behind the Scenes

The backend is written in Go and handles all networking responsibilities. It inspects active network interfaces, determines local IP configuration, and runs a UDP-based discovery engine that broadcasts and listens for peer announcements.

Each device periodically broadcasts its identity to the local network. Devices running Net Reader listen on a shared port, build a peer table, and remove inactive peers automatically using timestamps.

The frontend, built with React, consumes a local API exposed by the Go server and visualizes network state in a simple, readable interface.

📦 Current vs Planned Features

FeatureStatus
LAN Peer DiscoveryImplemented
Network Interface InspectionImplemented
Peer Visibility in UIImplemented
Peer-to-Peer MessagingPlanned
File SharingPlanned
TCP Connections After DiscoveryPlanned

🧭 Design Philosophy

Net Reader avoids requiring router configuration, administrative network access, or centralized servers. All discovery happens using standard LAN techniques that work within normal home and office networks.

This makes the project both practical and realistic, closely mirroring how LAN games, device discovery protocols, and peer-to-peer tools operate in the real world.

📘 License

Net Reader is released under the MIT License and is intended to be explored, modified, and extended as a learning resource.

🔗 Reference

Source: GitHub Repository
